 1. THE PROJECT A. Background I . Since the start of the ERP, the Government of Ghana (GoG) has, under vanrous donor- funded programs, sought to improve its financial management. Under the Structural Adjustment Institutional Support Project (SAIS)' which accompanied and complemented the Bank's first Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC I), progress was made in, among other areas, external debt management, tax administration, and policy analysis. The Economic Management Support Project (EMS), which was approved by the Board in 1991, further sought improvements in budgeting, auditing, expenditure reporting, and tax administration. In particular, it supported the introduction of an Integrated Personnel and Payroll Database (IPPD) which linked personnel information to payroll and allowed for the automated processing of the Government payroll and analysis of personnel information. The Debt Recording and Management System (DRMS), developed by the Commonwealth Secretariat, was installed and operationalized in the Aid and Debt Management Unit (ADMU) of the Ministry of Finance, the Bank of Ghana (BoG), and the Controller and Accountant-General's Department (CAGD). Customs administration was improved through the introduction of the Automated System for Customs Database (ASYCUDA) which was extended to the primary ports. The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit (FINSAC) has addressed institutional strengthening of the Institute of Chartered Accountants (ICA) and the banking sector by the introduction of accounting standards through the Ghana Accounting Standards Board and of new legislation improving financial reporting supervision on the part of the BoG. It has also supported a diagnostic study of the Audit Service which has come up with recommendations on enhancing the capabilities of the Audit Service. However, these efforts were of a piece-meal nature and were not guided by the requirements of an integrated financial management system. 2. The Government is now committed to implanting an integrated financial management system in the country. The motivation for this is from three sources. First, better financial management is critical to effective macroeconomic management and outcomes, particularly in an era of uncertain donor flows. Second, with Ghana adopting a democratic government since 1992, higher levels of accountability are perceived as critical to consolidating and sustaining the democratic process. The 1992 Constitution has set the framework for greater participation of citizens in society and has specifically defined the roles and responsibilities of the judicial, legislative and executive arms of Government to create the basis for maintaining the necessary set of checks and balances essential to a democratic society. Third, effective financial management, particularly at the decentralized local level, is a pre-condition to the implementation of the Government's decentralization program which is embedded in the Constitution. B. Detailed Project Description 3. The Project will develop an integrated public financial management system in Ghana. This is an inter-related set of sub-systems which plans, processes, and reports upon financial resources, covers a broad spectrum of financial management areas, and is computer-based. The principal factor which "integrates" the system is a common, reliable, unified database to, and from which, all financial data flows and which is shared by all the financial users. 1 Approved in 1987 and closed in 1993.
 2 4. The Project will support the development of eight critical components or sub-systems (the shaded boxes in Chart 1): (i) the budget preparation sub-system; (ii) the budget implementation sub-system; (iii) the accounting sub-system; (iv) the cash management sub-system; (v) the aid and debt management sub-system; (vi) the revenue sub-system; (vii) the procurement sub-system; and (viii) the auditing sub-system. Even though these eight components are functionally different, the first three components are logically united in their operations and the Project seeks to develop them as such. Thus, a comprehensive Budget and Public Expenditure Management System (BPEMS) wvill be developed which will integrate in a single common system the information systems for budget preparation, budget implementation, and accounting. The following sections provide a description of the individual components of the Project. Budget Preparation Sub-System 5. Problem. The current process of budget preparation has several weaknesses, some of which were identified by the 1993 PER. These weaknesses have generally led to a lack of ownership of the budget by the sector ministries and has undermined the utility of the budget as an instrument for achieving national priorities and for managing the financial resources of the government. 6. Some of the main weaknesses in budget preparation are: (a) preparation of the recurrent budget on an incremental basis, i.e. by adding a certain percentage (based, for instance, on inflation) to the previous year's estimates of expenditures, without reviewing whether the particular activities are in line with government priorities or whether they are being implemented in the most cost-effective manner; (b) absence of a medium-term outlook, or a lack of forward planning, of the recurrent budget such that forward estimates of the recurrent costs of current policies and programs are not developed, (c) lack of critical review of the government's own priorities in the preparation of the development budget, and the absence of the estimation of its recurrent cost implications and whether sufficient funds will be available to cover these recurrent costs; and (d) lack of adequate budget guidance to the ministries, including the lack of hard expenditure ceilings in the budget guidelines reflecting the Government's expenditure priorities. 7. The above weaknesses in the budgeting process result in an inappropriate allocation of resources. The need for restructuring of public expenditures is particularly acute now because (a) a successful inflation management strategy is critically dependent on prudent public expenditure management; (b) strategies for economic reform and poverty alleviation (being developed by the Government will) require changes in the budget, both inter- and intra-sectorally; and (c) scope for additional revenue generation is limited and the future of donor flows increasingly uncertain. Hence, for an accelerated growth strategy, the efficiency of public expenditures is critical. 2 2 In the short-term, such efforts may be constrained by the large size of wage and wage-related expenditures (the restructuring of which will need to await the outcome of the National Institutional Renewal Program-NIRP) and the interest burden.

 4 8. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The basic objective of this component is to improve the planning and budgeting of public expenditures and thus contribute to strengthened fiscal policy formulation and implementation. For this component, the Project will focus on the following sets of issues: (a) instituting a Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF) as part of the normal budgetary process. This would involve (i) formulating program categories for planning, budgeting and accounting; (ii) integrating of aid financed projects and programs; (iii) preparing expenditure program profiles for each MDA showing the object-wise outlays; (iv) ensuring that the forecasts are limited to current or existing policies; (v) specifying the price basis; (vi) formulating a budget calendar, indicating the preparation, review, and consolidation of these rolling forecasts; (vii) specifying the linkages between the forecasts and the annual budget; and (viii) preparing a computer software for the purpose. The coverage of the MTEF would be over both the recurrent and the development budget. This would complement the BPEMS system and would be fully integrated with it. Several elements of an MTEF already exist in Ghana. For instance, an aggregative three-year expenditure and revenue framework already exists under the Policy Framework Paper (PFP) for 1995-97 (which will be updated in 1996). Medium-term expenditure programming at the sectoral level either exists or is being developed in three key sectors (Roads & Highways, Health, and Basic Education) in the context of their sector investment programs which are being supported by the Bank. In addition, a rolling three-year Public Investment Program has been prepared by the Government for some years. (b) improvements in the formulation of the annual budget. These improvements would include (i) preparation of a model budget circular indicating the possible expenditure ceilings within which MDA budgets have to be formulated; (ii) development of a software for the Budget Division that will facilitate budget preparation; (iii) preparation and installation of the budget software in the MDAs; (iv) arrangements for the eventual electronic transmission of budget proposals from MDAs to the Budget Division of the Ministry of Finance; and (v) program for consolidation and preparation of draft budgets. The budget software referred to above would enable the use of the historical, baseline, and ceiling data for budgeting purposes, facilitate the iterative process of budget submission, consolidation, revision, and finalization, provide for the tracking of the budget process from initial proposal to Parliamentary approval and printing, produce a master copy in a form suitable for presentation to Parliament and subsequent printing. It will also permit the development of implications of rolling expenditure plans and provide program profiles requiring special attention. This system will be an integral part of the BPEMS referred to above. (c) the training of a core group of budget and finance staff from the Ministry of Finance, the NDPC, and the MDAs in the preparation of an MTEF and the annual budget, and in the use of the information systems in its preparation.
 5 Budget Implementation Sub-System 9. Problem. The key problem identified in this area relates to deficient expenditure monitoring and control systems. The lack of timely, accurate, and current information on budget allocations, comnmitments and actual expenditures seriously undermines the Government's capacity for fiscal management, leading to an inefficient allocation of resources and obscuring public accountability. Even though the 1979 Financial Administration Decree (FAD) and the corresponding Financial Administration Regulations (FAR) set out the basic principles of financial reporting, monitoring, and control, these are often not adhered to. For instance, commitments are irregularly recorded and reported by the ministries. In the absence of such records, expenditure monitoring is resorted to on the basis of 'checks cleared' by the BoG or, as more recently, 'checks issued' by the CAGD. Because of delays inherent in each step of payment processing, the Ministry of Finance is able to monitor these expenditures only with considerable time lags undermining expenditure monitoring and control, and necessitating the imposition of across-the-board cuts towards the end of the year to maintain aggregate fiscal discipline. Undue delays in reporting make it difficult to promptly close and prepare the financial accounts of the Government. 10. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The basic objective of this component is to ensure an orderly and smooth implementation of the budget, while providing adequate flexibility to the MDAs to manage their programs and projects, as well as to enable the Ministry of Finance to maintain oversight that is in conformity with the requirements of macroeconomic stabilization. This will be developed through the following sets of activities under the Project. (a) the design and implementation of a Budget Classification System which is consistent with the Chart of Accounts so as to permit the reporting of expenditures by the same codes as in the budget. (b) the functional design of systems, processes, and procedures for expenditure controls. This will involve all aspects of expenditure control prior to making payment authorizations, such as checking for budget appropriations, prior commitments, verification for receipt of goods and services, as well as the development of reporting formats, necessary laws and regulations, and operating manuals. (c) the implementation of a computerized system (including software) to support the above functional design. This system would be capable of providing timely, reliable, and up-to- date information on budget allocations, commitments, and actual expenditures, and would enable the production of periodic financial reports so as to permit monitoring and management of the actual expenditures by individual spending ministries and by CAGD. This system will be fully integrated with the Accounting Sub-System (see paras I 1-12 below) and the software for the Budget Division mentioned above. (d) the training of budget, finance, and treasury staff in the MDAs in budget implementation. Accounting Sub-System 11. Problem. The main problems identified in the accounting sub-system relate to (a) the lack of a unified Chart of Accounts; (b) ignorance, non-compliance with, and obsolescence of elements of the 1979 FAD and the 1979 FAR; and (c) the lack of an adequate cadre of trained, qualified accounting staff in the line ministries as well as in the CAGD. These problems, in conjunction
 6 with those identified in budget implementation, were the prime reasons why the Consolidated Accounts of the Central Government were not produced annually over 1983-92 even though the annual submission of these is required by the FAD. It is only since 1993 that these accounts have been prepared annually. 12. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The objectives of the accounting sub- system are to (i) promote a system of accounting that shows the effective utilization of the financial resources of the country; (ii) provide a window to the public to ascertain the financial status of the Government; and (iii) serve as a major instrument in the formulation and implementation of Government policies. The project would seek to implant a modem accounting sub-system which classifies, records and analyses in a timely, reliable, and standard manner all government financial transactions. This sub-system would provide all basic financial transaction data and reports to all other sub-systems and will form the core of the financial management system being envisaged. Key activities would include: (a) formulation of a comprehensive Chart of Accounts covering receipts, expenditures, and borrowing. The Chart of Accounts would be coded, reflect the function, MDA, program, and items of expenditure, reflect the needs of each MDA, facilitate a link-up with the development plan, and a link-up with the National Income Accounts. (b) introduction of a common General Ledger System; (c) reporting by Treasuries and consolidation of Treasury Reports by CAGD; (d) revised formulation of annual operating statements to be provided by the CAGD; (e) specification of Accounting Standards for Government. This would require the introduction of new regulations for government-wide accounting; (f) eventual electronic link-up with the payroll and pension systems; (g) installation of an effective payments system including electronic payments where possible; (h) the training of government accounting staff in the new system. Cash Management Sub-System 13. Problem. Organized cash management does not exist in Ghana as is evidenced by the following problems: (a) there is no cash flow plan that readily identifies and matches the flow of revenues with those of disbursements, and provides forward estimates so as to form the basis for planning the Government's borrowing requirements. As a result, the BoG open market sales of treasury bills do not accurately reflect the liquidity position of the Government; (b) there is lack of a system for prompt reporting of transactions and balances of the Consolidated Fund to which all revenues are to be deposited and from which all disbursements are to be made; (c) there is a large float of revenues constantly in the system reflecting the lags in the transfer to the BoG of, for instance, revenues collected by the local offices of the revenue agencies and deposited with the local commercial banks. While these are cash assets of the Government, they are not represented as such as they are captured only when the revenues are transferred into the Consolidated Fund at
 7 the BoG; and (d) there is no integration between the preparation and execution of the budget, and the determination of the cash requirements of the Government. 14. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The objective of the cash management component is to achieve an efficient provision of the cash resources of the Government while voiding the immobilization of resources and minimizing the costs of borrowing. This will be achieved through the introduction of a modem cash management system which will estimate, project, monitor, and manage revenue inflows and expenditure outflows. Key activities under the Project would include: (a) preparation and submission of cash needs by MDAs; (b) review by the Ministry of Finance of the above cash forecasts and linking them with resource flow forecasts; (c) coordination of the releases made by the Ministry of Finance, MDAs, CAGD, and BoG; (d) determining public sector borrowing requirements on the basis of the cash flows; (e) the automation of the cash management system to permit real-time reconciliation between the CAGD, the Bank of Ghana, and the Budget Division of the Ministry of Finance; (f) the development of a policy for the management of the cash assets including the rules governing BoG treatment of the Consolidated Account and the financial arrangement between the Government and the commercial banks on fees and interest payments. Aid and Debt Management Sub-System 15. Problem. The problems with respect to Ghana's debt management-both external and domestic-are pnrmanrly two: (i) A single set of accounts on the country's external debt does not exist. The ADMU of the Ministry of Finance is the unit charged, in principle, with the responsibility of recording, monitoring, and projecting data on external debt, and authorizing disbursements. Through Bank assistance under SAIS and EMS, the ADMU operationalized the CS-DRMS. The data coverage of this system is still incomplete. In particular, information on Government guarantees on external debt of parastatals and private agencies is not captured. As a result, knowledge of the GoG's external current (and potential) indebtedness is incomplete. This is a potentially problematic situation particularly vis-a-vis the timely payment of Ghana's external debt obligations; and (ii) The recording and management of domestic debt remains a BoG operation with no linkage with the ADMU. No database exists which captures government liabilities.3 The same is true on the asset side of the Government's balance sheet (i.e. net lending by the Government), too. This is, however, being addressed under a separate Bank project, the Privatization and Public Enterprise Development Technical Assistance Project II, which is helping the development of a database to capture information on Government assets-loans to parastatals and private organizations.
 8 16. Proposed Project Goals and Activities. The objective of this component is to strengthen the management of the acquisition, servicing, and retirement ofpublic debt. Key activities would include: (a) the integration of the external debt database between the ADMU, the BoG, and the CAGD (including the establishment of an electronic link-up) so as to provide a single complete status of Ghana's external debt. This is an activity in an advanced stage of completion. (b) the full operationalization of an Aid (external loans and grants) Management Information System (AMIS), currently under development; (c) the integration of information on technical cooperation, currently incorporated in the system of the National Technical Cooperation and Assistance Program (NaTCAP), with AMIS;4 (d) the strengthening of ADMU as the focal point for external debt data; (e) the training of staff from the ADMU in areas such debt portfolio analysis, negotiation skills, international finance, budgeting, and information technology related to their operational work. Revenue Management Sub-System 17. The objective of the reformns in revenue management is to promote systems of administratiuon aimed at achieving greater taxpayer compliance and convenience, and to increase the efficiency of revenue collection, reporting, andforecasting. The problems and proposed reforms in each of the revenue sub-components is provided below: Internal Revenue 18. Problem. Significant strides have been made during the ERP in the collection of direct taxes by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Yet greater efficiency gains can be made and are increasingly important given the paucity of additional new sources of revenues. The following weaknesses have been identified in internal revenue: (a) the lack of a unique (and common to other tax agencies) tax identification number which would permit greater inter-agency collaboration and enable higher revenue collection. Currently, taxpayers are able to change districts freely and thereby avoid paying taxes or to have several sources of income but only declare income from one source; (b) the lack of adequate computer facilities which would allow for the timely integration of data from IRS offices across the country, and its expeditious deposit onto the Consolidated Account at the BoG; (c) weak capacity, particularly in the areas of tax audit, tax examination, and records management. 19. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The primary objective of the investments in the IRS would be to improve taxpayer compliance and to increase the efficiency of revenue forecasting, collection, and reporting by the IRS. To that end, the Project would support the following activities: 4 The responsibility for NaTCAP has been transferred from the NaTCAP Secretariat to ADMU.
 9 (a) the development and introduction of a unique and common Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN); (b) the development of a computer-based system for tax assessment, collection, reporting, follow-up, and analysis; (c) the enhancement of tax audit, tax examination, records management capacities of the IRS; (d) installation of an electronic internal audit system; and (e) training in the areas of management, taxation, finance, accounting, budgeting, research, policy, and forward estimation. Customs, Excise, and Preventive Services 20. Problem. Customs administration in Ghana suffers from three main problems: (a) deficiencies in policies and procedures which hinder trade; (b) the lack of trained managers and customs officials; and (c) outdated nature of computer equipment for customs purposes. These problems have also been the subject of discussion under the Trade and Investment Gateway Project being developed by the Bank which will address the first two problems in its project design. This Project will support the third component which is more directly related to the flow of revenue information in a timely and reliable manner. However, the development and implementation of these computer-related needs would be contingent on the reforms in policies and procedures and developed by the Bank as a joint package. 21. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The primary objective of this project component is to enhance taxpayer convenience and to maximize the efficiency of revenue collection, reporting, andforecasting. To that end, the Project would support the following activities: (a) an independent assessment of the customs data management system; (b) the development, and implementation, of a medium-term strategy for the modernization of customs data management and related computer needs; and (c) the provision of training in customs data management and related areas. Other types of training such as for management purposes would be provided under the Trade and Investment Gateway Project. Indirect Tax Reforms 22. Problem. The Value Added Tax (VAT) was introduced in Ghana in March 1995 as a replacement for the Sales Tax but had to be withdrawn within three months in the wake of protests against what was claimed to be its high inflationary impact. The Sales Tax was re-introduced along with a new Service Tax as a short-term measure while the indirect tax reforms were revisited and revised.
 10 23. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The objective of the new Indirect tax will be to maximize the generation of indirect tax revenue in the country while enforcing greater equity in taxation. This is to be achieved through a series of steps in the near- to medium-termn. These relate to: (a) determining the organizational status of indirect tax administration. This would specify the roles and responsibilities of the various tax agencies in indirect tax collection, their size and structure, relationship with the other revenue agencies, and to questions of whether the new indirect tax should be collected by a separate entity with nationwide operations, or whether it should be amalgamated into one of the revenue agencies from which economies of scale in tax collection and reporting can be derived, (b) reviewing the policy framework. This refers to companrsons with experiences in other African countries which have successfully introduced the VAT, such as Zambia and Uganda, review of the legal framework required, and a re-assessment of the publicity campaign or the communications strategy needed (including the training of staff) (c) designing a new indirect tax. This relates to the design of the level and structure of the tax rate, the nature and extent of exemptions, and the phasing-in of the implementation of the tax. (d) evaluating the current software for indirect tax collection. Changes in the design of the indirect tax, and the introduction of a TIN would require a re-evaluation of the software in use for the registration of taxpayers, and the processing of retums and refunds, and a likely purchase and customization of new software. (e) preparing for the launch of indirect tax reforms. This would include preparation of the legislative bill that will need to be developed to introduce the new tax and the development of the publicity program. (f) providing logistical support to the introduction of the new tax in terms of equipment and supplies. (g) training of staff as well as taxpayers. The former need training in the technical aspects of the tax and its collection, while the latter in areas of tax payment and record-keeping. National Revenue Secretariat 24. Problem. The National Revenue Secretariat (NRS) was set up under the SAIS project as a central revenue coordinating and policymaking body. It was to be an autonomous body outside of the Ministry of Finance, under a Cabinet Minister. It was charged with overseeing improvements in tax collection, developing analytical capacity for tax policy analysis, formulating tax and revenue policy, and preparing regular revenue estimates and projections. This was part of the "enclave" approach to tax and customs administration in Ghana which Bank reviews have identified it as one of the successful reform initiatives and which spearheaded the increase in tax revenues from a 6.5
 11 percent of GDP in 1984 to 16.2 percent of GDP by 1994.5 But since then, changes in management leadership and the incorporation of the NRS into the Ministry of Finance as a revenue unit have obscured its function and identity, and undermined its utility. 25. Project Component Objectives and Activities. The objective of this component would be to clarify the role of the NRS and its relationship with the other revenue agencies and the Ministry of Finance. The Project would support: (a) an independent assessment of the organizational status and role of the NRS, including its relationship with the other revenue agencies, with a view to making recommendations for a rational and efficient solution. Audit Sub-System 26. Problem. Audit requirements in Ghana are covered by the 1972 Audit Service Decree, the 1979 FAD, and, to a certain degree, by the 1992 Constitution. In October 1995, Coopers & Lybrand, Accra, began a diagnostic study of the Ghana Audit Service-financed under the Bank's Financial Sector Adjustment Credit (FINSAC)-which conducts external audits. Several problems have been identified including weak technical skills and professional development, deficiencies in the professional mix of staff, lack of use of computer technology, and inadequacy of logistics and supplies. Internal audit also remains very weak. The FAD empowers the Auditor-General to make arrangements for carrying out internal audits but concerns over potential conflict of interest prompted the Auditor-General to assign the internal audit function to the Controller and Accountant-General's Department in 1987. But this is also an unsatisfactory arrangements as the accountants are now the internal auditors also. 27. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The objective of this component is to promote the timely and effective audit of transactions to ensure that resources are being usedfor the specified purposes. Modern auditing seeks to attain the highest level of accountability and transparency in the public sector through the implementation of the internal audit of accounts and financial operations performed by qualified personnel reporting to the chief executive officer of the institution, and a posterior external audit performed by a qualified supreme audit institution that is legally, financially, and politically independent of the executive branch and reports to an elected legislative body representing citizens in general. Internal Audit (a) institution of effective internal audit, (b) reporting on internal audit; (c) institutional arrangement for internal audit. Procurement Sub-System 28. Problem. To maximize expected gains in transparency and efficiency, the reforns of public financial management would benefit from complementary reforms in the public sector's procurement policies. The current procurement practices suffer from various deficiencies which were recently diagnosed by a Bank report.6 Two key deficiencies are: (a) the multiplicity of practices for the procurement of goods and services. The only formal rules and regulations are incorporated in the Ghana Supplies Commission (GSC) Law which conducts no more than a quarter of all public procurement in the country. Other procurement agencies use Bank and other donors procurement guidelines. While this serves immediate needs of all concerned, it exposes the country to potential problems when the country is required to depend on its own laws for remedying procurement disputes and issues. In addition, even the current practice leaves bare the area of local procurement and prevents the country from using National Competitive Bidding (NCB) procedures in Bank-financed contracts; and (b) lack of timely processing and reporting to the CAGD on public procurement, largely on account of manual processing of all purchases and payments. 29. Proposed Component Objectives and Activities. The objective of this component is to streamline the procurement of goods, works, and services, and establish an effective monitoring and tracking system. The Project would support the following: (a) the review of public procurement practices in Ghana with a view to formulating a national procurement code and establishing mechanisms for monitoring compliance with the code. In general, the following principles will be followed: (a) use application software packages already existent in the market, with the required customization; (b) select application packages that run under UNIX and use a Relational Database Management System (RDBMS); and (c) set up the hardware in a Local Area Network (LAN) shape, interconnecting the different LAN servers in a distributed architecture. 31. Application Software. For each project component, the GoG will try to identify the application software package already existent in the market that most closely satisfies its data processing needs. This package should be able to run on computers of different capacity in accordance to the volume of transactions at each location. In addition, to avoid hardware restrictions, the software will follow an "open system" concept to ensure portability to different hardware platforms. In practice, the environment that comes closest to this concept is the UNIX operating system; consequently, the software package will run under UNIX. In order to facilitate the use of the package by the GoG, it would be desirable that the application would use an RDBMS and that it was developed using a Fourth Generation Language (4GL). Furthernore, use of a Graphical User Interface (GUI) will offer a user-friendly enviromnent for data entry and access. 32. In summary, the GoG will try to identify UNIX-based software packages, for instance for government accounting, developed using a 4GL and a RDBMS, interacting with the end-user through a GUI, which with appropriate customization will be used at the different units. 33. Hardware. With respect to the hardware, each unit will need several workstations for various tasks such as to enter the accounting transactions, undertake queries or print reports. Since the information will have to be consolidated and shared, at each location a server will be interconnected with the workstations forning a LAN. Each unit's budget and its expenditures infornation will be stored in the server and, with adequate security restrictions, the workstations will be able to retrieve and update the data in the server. If adequate communications facilities are available, individual unit servers will be connected to the servers in the regional offices which, in tum, will be interconnected to the main server in Accra. This will constitute a "distributed architecture" network in which each unit, regional office and central server are "nodes." Each node will have its own data processing and database management capability and summary or detailed data, as required, will be sent to the main server. Where such connections will not be feasible, diskettes containing the data will be sent periodically. Since each node will have the computing power most appropriate to its requirements, resource utilization will be optimized and eventual malfunction of one node will not affect the others. In addition, end-users at each unit will have responsibility over their LAN and, as a result, a sense of ownership. Human Resource Development 34. The project design strongly emphasizes human resource development in order to provide staff with opportunitiesfor the transfer and acquisition of new skills and to contribute to a core of trainedfinancial managers in Government. Given weak local capacity, the provision of
 14 adequate training is critical to the sustainability of the Project and to the reform program. The training under the Project can be divided into six types, depending on the audience and the nature of the training: (a) specific training to key Government staff in the principles, concepts, and methodologies for the subject areas covered by the project components; this is training related to the operational work of the staff, (b) general training to the people in the financial management chain related to aspects of financial management such as accounting, budgeting, policymaking, taxation, etc. which are relevant to; (c) general training to staff in standard computer software packages; (d) training to senior-level management and policymakers in the use of computer-based financial management information systems; (e) end-user training in the use of the computer-based financial management information systems; and (f) technical training to GoG system analysts and programmers in the use of the specific tools to be employed for developing and implementing the information systems under the Project, such as RDBMS, or UNIX operating system. 35. The Project will provide for such training in the context of an overall training strategy primarily using domestic resources and facilities. Training will be based on separate training needs assessments for each agency. These would identify the current capabilities, the areas for training, and the mechanisms for providing it. This will also take into account the existing training facilities in these agencies and in the public sector generally. Most system-related training would be provided by the system vendors as part of their system implementation. External training would be limited to only those skills relevant to the success of the Project which cannot be obtained locally. External providers of training will be used to train local trainers. The Project would permit a limited number of structured Study Tours for key staff involved in the implementation of the Project to learn from what other countries have done in modernizing their financial management systems. Legal Framework Revision 36. The Project would support the revision of the legal framework for financial administration in Ghana with a view to providing an adequate legalframeworkforfinancial management which ensures transparency and accountability. This would require (i) a review of the current legislative framework in the light of the changed political and institutional arrangements and practices; and (ii) the development of revised financial rules and regulations to be submitted to Parliament for approval.

Communications Strategy 38. The Project recognizes the need for an effective communications strategy for the Project in order to promote an understanding of the content and usefilness of the financial management reforms being introduced. This will be addressed through two initiatives: (i) Inception Workshops, and (ii) publication of a newsletter. 39. Inception Workshops. A series of Inception Workshops has been launched to (a) reinforce the concept ofjoint ownership and responsibility forfinancial management in government, and (b) ensure the fuillest acceptance, participation, and cooperation of all key players in public financial management. To these ends, the workshops will address the what, why and how of the reform program, and elicit the thoughts and ideas of the participants which will then feed into the design of the reforms. In particular, the workshops will educate the participants on the objectives and scope of the reform program, outline what the benefits are likely to be and how the participants would gain from them directly, explain how the public financial management reform program would fit into ongoing institutional reform initiatives, discuss what the roles and functions of the key players in financial management should be, and discuss how the sustainability and success of the reforms can be ensured. 40. These workshops would be targeted at (a) ministers, key presidential staffers, and chief directors; (b) accounting, treasury, and budget officers; (c) managers in various line ministries, and (d) private sector agents such as the private contractors, the Chamber of Commerce, the Private Sector Roundtable, joumalists, academics, and local think-tanks; and (e) other target groups in civil society. 41. These workshops were started with the launch of PUFMARP by the Minister of Finance at a tvo-day Workshop for senior civil servants in July, 1995. Subsequently, the Controller and Accountant-General discussed the program with his staff from across the country at his annual staff conference in September, 1995. Later, in July 1996, a workshop was organized with the sector ministries in Accra on Budget and Public Expenditure Management. More Inception Workshops are planned at the central, and regional levels. These workshops will be funded under the Project. Additional funds through the Client Consultation Funds provided by the World Bank are also being used to finance these workshops. 42. PUFMARP Newsletter. A newsletter will be produced by the Project Management and distributed widely within Government, to the donors, and the private sector to (i) disseminate information on the status of the reforms, (ii) announce implementation schedules, and (iii) provide examples of the latest and state-of-the-art practices in financial management from Ghana, Africa, and the World. This newsletter will be produced quarterly initially with the frequency increased to every two months as project implementation gathers speed.

 31 Annex C Terms of Reference for Consultancy Services for the Design and Implementation of a Budget and Public Expenditure Management System for the Government of Ghana Issued October 1995 I. Introduction 1. The Government of Ghana's Public Expenditure Review for 1993 highlighted several problems including weak budget preparation, weak expenditure monitoring and control mechanisms and the lack of a proper accounting system. Subsequently, the GoG with inputs from the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), the Overseas Development Administration (ODA), and the World Bank developed a medium-term strategy for reforming the public financial management system. This strategy seeks to develop an integrated public.financial management system. This strategy has since been adopted by the Cabinet and forms the basis for planned measures to be supported by technical assistance from ODA, CIDA, and the World Bank. 2. Some elements of an integrated public financial management system already exist in Ghana or are being implemented -- for instance, the customs system, a debt management system, and an Integrated Personnel and Payroll Database (IPPD). Since 1994, there have also been significant positive developments in governmental accounting and financial reporting. But there remains a strong need to strengthen and consolidate these developments. The GoG has prioritized key areas for immediate action -- budgeting, public accounting, and financial reporting. The GoG consequently wishes to proceed to set up a modem Budget and Public Expenditure Management System (BPEMS). These terms of reference provide a description of the technical assistance required by GoG to develop and implement the BPEMS component of its overall public financial management reform program as provided in Table 1. This BPEMS will be implemented in Ministries, Departments, and Agencies in Accra and all other regional capitals. 3. The GoG therefore invites qualified firms, with experience in the design and implementation of computer-based government financial management systems to assist in this project. Extensive experience in the design and implementation of similar systems for other government agencies. Previous experience in the implementation of similar systems in less developed countries or in countries of the British Commonwealth will be an advantage. Part of the services required under this project could be satisfactorily carried out by local firms. International firms are required to enter into partnerships with at least one local firm in both the design and the implementation of BPEMS. 4. The consultants will need to work closely with GoG officials in the various financial organs of the Government which have responsibility for fiscal management processes, including, inter-alia, the offices of the Controller and Accountant General (CAG), the Ministry of Finance (MoF), the Bank of Ghana (BoG), and the various Ministries, Departments, and Agencies
 32 Table I PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT REFORM COMPONENT AND ELEMENTS Financial Systems Study Capacity Building Financial Legislation and Development of I I Regulations Manuals Accounting System Change Management Revision & Consolidation of Budget Manual Design Financial Legislation and Regulations Budget Management Human Resource Governmental (Composite Broad-Based) Development Accounting & Reporting Manual Payroll Management Public Expenditure Management Revenue Management Decentralized Financial Management & Reporting Procurement and Contract Management Cash Management Investments Management Receivables Management Fixed Assets & Inventory Management Aid and Debt Management Pensions Management Comprehensive Auditing Related Information Technology
 33 (MDAs), etc. The consultants will report to the Project Manager who will head a Project Team which is to be set up by the GoG. The Project Team will work under the auspices of a Steering Committee which is headed by the Deputy Minister of Finance and includes the Controller and Accountant General, the Chief Director of the Ministry of Finance, and representatives from some key line ministries. The Project Team will include well qualified professionals in financial management and information technology for whom an international search is underway. II. Objectives 5. The fundamental objective of BPEMS is to implement a reliable, scientifically developed, computerized, broad-based budget and public expenditure management system that is capable of providing accurate, timely, and up-to-date information on commitments, actual expenditures, budget allocations and financial reports in order to: (a) enable MoF to institute a scientific, pragmatic, and meaningful budgetary system for the country; (b) enable the MDAs and Metropolitan, Municipal, and District Assemblies (MMDAs) to better manage their budgets and ensure that sectoral budget allocations are not exceeded; (c) enable the MoF to ensure effective implementation and adherence to the national budget; (d) provide a basis for improved financial management in Government; (f) enable the CAG to fulfill his statutory functions of reporting on the national public accounts; (g) enable prompt and accurate reconciliation of the national public accounts with the accounts of the Bank of Ghana, MDAs, and MMDAs; and (h) enhance public accountability. 6. BPEMS will be designed to meet the needs of users of financial information. Such a system would need to be comprehensive in terms of coverage and be a source of reliable and timely data to become a credible source of information for users. It will provide an integrated government-wide budgeting and accounting system, will encompass the functional requirements for the budget preparation, budget execution, budget evaluation, and accounting processes and would cover the appropriation, commitment, funds allocation, and payment processes for both the recurrent and the development budget of both centralized and decentralized governmental agencies and institutions. The system should also facilitate the proposed devolution of financial responsibility to MDAs, and MMDAs.
 34 III. Scope of Work 7. The Scope of Work for this consultancy involves the tasks associated with the design and implementation of the above systems including the specification of the hardware and software requirements and the provision of training. 8. BPEMS will be implemented in a phased manner. In Phase I, BPEMs will be designed, specifications developed for the required hardware and softvare, and procurement arrangements will be completed. It is anticipated that this can be completed by March 31, 1996. In Phase II, BPEMS will be implemented in at least seven priority ministries by June 30, 1996. The seven priority ministries are: Ministry of Finance (including the Controller and Accountant General's Department), Ministry of Roads and Highways, Ministry of Works and Housing, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Information, and Ministry of Local Government and rural Development. (The exact coverage of departments and agencies under the ministries will be determined later.). In Phase III, PBEMS will be replicated across remaining ministries in Accra and the regional capitals. This will be completed by December 31, 1997. 9. Each phase will normally start upon substantial completion of the preceding phase and will be contingent upon the satisfactory completion and acceptance by GoG and the World Bank of the deliverables listed for that phase. The aim of the prioritization of the implementation is to ensure that the consultant executes the contract in accordance with the TORs and at the same time to enable a phased handing over of the products to the Govermment. The consultant will be required to present monthly Project Status Report to the Project Manager. The report will specify activities conducted by the consultant during the preceding month; problems encountered, if any, and proposed solutions; and activities expected to be performed during the following month. 10. The tasks and major deliverables associated with each phase of the project are listed below: IV. Phase I: Systems Design and Specification of Hardware and Software Requirements A. Preparation of the detailed functional design and requirements for the specified systems and development of specifications for the Technology Architecture required for the implementation of these systems. 11. The tasks involved in this activity would include: (a) Studying the functional processes including administrative procedures, transaction documents, forms and information flows, data flow statistics, related to the accounting and reporting, payroll, pension, and cash management areas currently in use. (b) Developing and defining a new set of functional processes, information flows, procedures, transaction types and associated documents and forms, and related structures required to set up the new system. (c) Developing a full functional design for the computer systems required, including the specification of the major data bases and data entities, the outputs reports, the
 35 input formats, transaction documents, input screen designs, processing and controls for the systems required at various nodes of the information flow network, the interfaces and data flows between these nodes and with external systems. (d) Design of the Technology Architecture to implement the Information Systems. This would include drawing up specifications of the -1W and S/W to be installed at various nodes and the mode of interconnection of this Hardware and Software. The overall H1W, S/W strategy to be employed for implementation is determined by the fact that a Government-wide accounting system will require a multi-tiered network with modules at the central and regional office levels. The system would require facilities for generating, storing, and processing data at each level and for exchanging data between levels. The data volumes encountered could vary widely across the nodes of the network, dictating the size of the computer at each node. Application software should therefore be scaleable for small or large computers and usable on a variety of H/W platforms. The system should utilize a distributed computer architecture with computing power located at the various nodes of the network. The software environment should be portable to different platforms (UNIX-based) and use modern application development tools such as Relational Data Base Management Systems (RDBMS), Fourth Generation Languages (4GLS), and Graphical User Interfaces (GUls). The consultants should ensure that these aspects are kept in mind while developing the technology architecture. In view of the availability of local expertise on ORACLE, SYBASE, INFORMIX, WINDOWS, the consultant shall give preference to systems utilizing these tools. 12. This task would include: * Surveying GoG offices and budget at the central, regional, and district levels, to determine the locations where the computer systems would need to be implemented, the associated transaction volumes (current and projected) and data requirements, to determine sizes and configurations of the HIW, S/W to be installed at these nodes and the mode of the interconnection of the nodes between the center and the regions, to ensure accurate and timely data transfers between the nodes. * Preparing the specifications of the hardware, systems software, application development software, and the application software package required at the various sites for each phase of the project for incorporation in the tender documents. * Drawing up specifications for associated facilities required for the installation of the system, such as power stabilizers, UPSs, telecommunication interfaces, and computer site specifications for incorporation into the tender documents. 13. The primary deliverables for Phase I will be: Budget and Expenditure Mananement System * A Revised Budgetary Classification. * Functional Design document for the Information Systems. * Specifications for the hardware and software and related facilities.
 36 Accounting and Reporting System * A new Chart of Accounts consistent with the Budgetary Classification. * Functional Design document for the Information Systems. * Complete set of transaction documents, reporting formats, procedures, manuals (for both budgets and accounting) required for the implementation of the systems. * Application Systems design. * Technology Architecture including specifications for H/W, S/W, and Communications Systems and associated facilities. In addition, the organizational changes required to implement these systems should also be detailed. Such GoG divisions or units that need to be created or eliminated and changes in staffing requirements. B. Search for Application Software 14. On the basis of the functional analysis above, the consultants will investigate altematives for application softvare. This would include investigating and ascertaining which off- the-shelf software packages can meet the functional requirements as defined above. While conducting a search for software packages, the consultants will ensure that: (i) the software packages provide the required functionality; (ii) local support is available for the package and it is possible to obtain and install upgrades and/or changes to the packages in Ghana as they become available; (iii) the vendor for the package provides customization assistance as may be required or alternatively the package source code is available for making changes as may be required; (iv) the costs associated with any customization are identified clearly in the total cost; (v) the package runs on a range of hardware and operating software which is compliant with the hardware/software strategy proposed for the systems (above); (vi) adequate documentation is available to enable package installation and use; and (vii) licensing arrangements clearly specify use of the package at multiple sites in Ghana. 15. The deliverables for this activity will be: The results of the application software package evaluation process with the selection of the application software which best meets the requirements of the proposed systems. C. Preparation of Tender Documents for the Acquisition of Hardware and Software 16. During this activity, the consultants will assist the Government in the procurement of the H/W and S/W. The consultants will: (a) Incorporate the Hardware and Software Specifications prepared as part of the earlier task to prepare a request for proposals for procurement of the Hardware and Software. These tender documents should be prepared in accordance with the World Bank Procurement Guidelines and Procedures. It may be noted that the H/W, S/W will be procured via an integrated procurement package but will be delivered in several stages. Delivery will be, first, for the Pilot system and then, over a period of time, for the replication of the system at other sites. These
 37 specifications must include allowance for maintenance and support for the hardware and software for a period of 5 years, and for consumables for 5 years. H/W requirements should also address environmental requirements such as Uninterrupted Power Supply Units (UPSs), etc. (b) Develop criteria for the evaluation of vendor proposals. (c) Assist the Government in the tendering process and in evaluating vendor proposals and in the acquisition of the hardware and software. (d) Provide technical management and quality assurance of the vendor's work, plan and prepare for data conversion and systems acceptance testing. 17. The deliverables for this activity will be: * Specifications and bid documents for the procurement of Hardware and Software for the implementation * Evaluation Criteria for Hardware and Software and a test data required to ensure the proper functioning of the application software; * Assistance to the Government in the tendering process, in evaluating vendor proposals and in the acquisition of hardware and software. * Technical management and quality assurance of the vendor's work; * Data Conversion Plan; and * User Acceptance Test Plan. D. Preparation of a Detailed Implementation and Training Plan 18. The consultants will develop a detailed implementation plan and schedule listing all associated tasks and their logical dependencies. this schedule will show all tasks associated with the procurement and installation of the hardware and software, software customization, training of local personnel, and installation of the system at prescribed sites. 19. This also requires the consultants to assess the capacity of government officials to use and manage the recommended system and accordingly develop a detailed training plan for staff. This plan will ensure adequate capacity building in the ministries and suggest institutional arrangements for systems support and maintenance. 20. The key deliverable for this will be: * Implementation plan including schedule and responsibilities. * Assessment of staff capacity. * User Training Plan.
 38 V. Phase 11: Pilot Systems Implementation in Seven Ministries in Accra and the Regional Capitals 21. Pilot Systems implementation will involve: (i) the installation and tests of hardware and basic software (such as DBMS, Application Development tools etc.), (ii) installation and testing of the application software, and (iii) training operating system end-users. 22. The consultants will assist the GoG in managing the installation of the hardware, the basic software, and application software. Each of these tasks are discussed in detail below: (a) Installation of Hardware. The consultants will assist GoG in supervising the supplier in the installation and testing of the hardware procured. This would include supervision of site preparations for the hardware including electrical power requirements, voltage stabilizers, telecommunications, and other elements as required. The consultant will also perform all required hardware acceptance tests on behalf of the GoG. (b) Installation of Software. The consultants will assist the GoG with the implementation, testing of the application software and its customized version. This includes setting up any initial data tables, files, databases, etc. as required by the application.. The consultants would be required to assist the Government in quality assurance tests to ensure that the application packages have the required functionality. In case a package requires customization to meet specified functional requirements, the consultant will specify the changes required and arrange for the changes to be implemented. (c) The consultants will insure the availability of the documentation needed for the operation and maintenance of the application software as well as for end-user training. 23. Deliverables for this Phase include: * Assistance to the Government in the installation and testing of the hardware and software. * Ensuring that the H/W and S/W supplied by the selected vendors meets the design specifications. * Ensuring that tested systems modules, including the modules that will be implemented at the central, regional, and district offices are fully functional. * User manuals and other technical documentation to enable the full operation and maintenance of the systems. * Training manuals for end-users. * Training of sufficient local staff to a level which will enable them to operate and maintain the systems and to provide necessary end-user support.
 39 The latter three items are usually provided by the system vendors but the consultant will still be responsible for ensuring quality and volume. In case the vendors fall short, the consultant will be responsible for providing them. VI. Phase III: Replication of the System Across Remaining Ministries in Accra and the Regional Capitals 24. This phase will cover the replication of the systems to other ministries. Deliverables for this phase would include: * A replication plan and schedule for the system for all designated sites. * A document (check list) detailing tasks that need to be undertaken for replication of the system at a typical regional or district site. * Working closely with the H/W, S/W vendor to ensure that the first five replications are operational. * Training of sufficient local staff capable of carrying out subsequent replications. VII. Level of Effort Estimates 25. It is estimated that the project will require a total of about 75 man-months of effort to be provided by the selected firm of consultants. VIII. Background Information on Current Public Expenditure Management 26. Laws and Regulations. The statutes and regulations relating to the financial administration of public resources are found primarily in the following four documents: * The 1992 Constitution * The Financial Administration Decree, 1979 * The Financial Administration Regulations, 1979 * Departmental Accounting Instruction and Enabling Legislation of specific MDAs and MMDAs. 27. Budgetary Process. The Government of Ghana plans and executes its Budget in three stages: Stare 1: Planning and Preparation * MoF issues annual budget circular NOT later than six months before the end of each financial year (FAR 30). * Budgets for MDAs are prepared by MDAs and submitted to the Ministry of Finance by September 30.
 40 Stage 2: Analysis andApproval * The Ministry of Finance holds Budget Hearings in order to coordinate the requests for budgetary allocations between October I and November 15. * The Ministry of Finance presents the Budget to Parliament by November 30. * Parliament approves the Budget by December 31. * Approved Budgets are communicated to MDAs and MMDAs by the Ministry of Finance by January 31. Stage 3: Implementation and Monitorini * Minister of Finance issues General Warrant or if deemed appropriate a Provisional warrant authorizing disbursement of approved recurrent expenditure. (FAR 54 and 55) by Januarv 7. * CAG issues Treasurv Circular to MDAs and Treasuries by January 14. * MDAs issue Financial Encumbrances (FEs) to Treasuries on the basis of the approved Budget for recurrent expenditure (FAR 56) * Specific warrant approved by the MEFP issued under authority of respective Sector Minister or Head of Department to Controller and Accountant-General of disbursement of capital expenditure (FAR 60). * CAG issues Expenditure Authorization (EA) for each capital expenditure. * Respective MDAs and MMDAs manage, monitor, and control expenditure. MOF and CAGD direct and coordinate MDA expenditure management, monitoring and control. * Ministrv of Finance and CAG control and monitor budgetary performance. * CAGD, MDAs, and MMDAs prepare monthly and annual financial statement and reports on the public accounts of Ghana and on other government accounts to Cabinet and Parliament no later than three months after the end of the financial year. * Auditor-General audits public accounts and other government accounts and submits report to Parliament no later than six months after the end of the financial year. 28. Role of the CAG. The CAG is responsible for controlling and accounting for the approved Budget. The CAG has 160 Treasury Offices serving all MDAs and MMDAs as follows: * 13 Ministry Treasuries * 2 Pensions Treasuries * 1 10 District Treasuries * 4 Headquarters Stations * 33 Foreign Missions Stations 29. Detailed financial activity reports called Cashbook Transcripts are received from these Treasuries. There are basically four (4) types: * Payments (Salaries and Wages) Cashbook * Payments (Recurrent Expenditure) Cashbook * Payments (Capital Expenditure) Cashbook * Payments (Debt Servicing) Cashbook
 41 * Other Payments (such as Trust Funds, Deposits, and Advances) Cashbook * Receipts Cashbook 30. Flow of Financial Information and Transactions. The flow of public financial transactions is as follows: * Inputsfrom MDAs and MMDAs. These are provided manually in the form of Forms, Local Purchase Orders, Stores/Service Receipt Advises, Payment Vouchers, Warrants, and other forms. They are submitted to the Treasuries for processing and receipt/payment and subsequently recorded in the books of accounts of the MDAs and MMDAs. * Processing at the Local Treasury. The Treasuries undertake manual edits, verifications, and validation. All financial transactions are entered in manual ledgers (called F.E. jackets) and Cashbook transcripts are written weekly (manually) to capture all financial transactions during the week. These are then sent to the CAG Headquarters on a monthly basis for validation and consolidation. - Processing at CAG Headquarters. Verification, Validation, and Consolidation of the Cashbook transcripts received is undertaken by the Data Examinations Section. This process is manual. Verified and Validated inputs are input into the mainframe computer system. Checks are undertaken to ensure integrity of data which had been input. The Main Accounts are then obtained from the system. * Reconciliation. All Government of Ghana cheques are drawn on Bank of Ghana and cleared through designated commercial banks where necessary. Each Treasury/Finance Office undertakes its bank reconciliation by matching entries made in cash books with statements received from servicing banks. Bank statements from Bank of Ghana are also reconciled with returns of cheques issued from the Treasury/finance offices at the CAGD Head Office. 31. Volume of Transactions * Average monthly transactions, in addition to the computerized payroll processing number * 4,000 Financial Encumbrance (Adjustment) * 20,000 Commitment Entries * 34,000 Journal Entries * 17,000 Cash Payments A total of 75,000 financial transactions per month. 32. Computer Hardware and Software. The Department currently owns an IBM mainframe computer(IBM 9377 Model 80 running on the VSE/SP operating system computer). Other operating system software's on it are CICS/VS and DL/I . The system is currently being used to prepare the Government payroll and also the Government Accounts. The payroll system is in the process of complete migration to a new IBM RISC machine. The Accounts System is in-house
 42 developed. The main computer has in all sixty-four (64) dummy terminals and twenty (20) personal computers connected directly to it. 33. The IBM RISC/6000 runs on AIX UNIX and is networked to about 6 remote sites and connected directly to about five (5) Ministries including Ghana Education Service. There are about one hundred and twenty (120) personal computers and terminals connected to the system. An Integrated Payroll/Personnel package is being installed on it. When this package is fully operational, the payroll will be discontinued from the VSE System.

doc.abstracts: The fundamental objective of the Public Financial Management Technical Assistance Project is to enhance the efficiency accountability, and transparency of the financial management functions of the Government of Ghana (GOG). The project will support the development of eight critical components: a) budget preparation sub-system: this supports budget preparation according to the considered Government priorities and ensures the production of a financial plan; b) budget implementation component: providing for control and monitoring of Government expenditures; c) accounting component, permiting the classification, recording and analysis of all financial transactions; d) cash management component: managing cash assets through projections and monitoring of cash flows, and providing a basis for the public sector borrowing requirements during the year; e) aid and debt management component: managing the acquisition, servicing, and retirement of internal and external public debt; f) revenue component: achieving increased efficiency in the collection, reporting, and forecasting of all revenues; g) procurement component: procuring and delivering goods and services, with appropriate regard to price competition, quality control and administrative expense; and h) auditing component: the safeguarding and control of all government resources through internal and external reviews of Government performance.
